The Zeiss Research Award (stylized as ZEISS Research Award and known as the Carl Zeiss Research Award up to 2013 ) is a prize for "outstanding achievements in the field of international research". The award has been sponsored and presented by Carl Zeiss AG since 2016. It is awarded every second year.
History
The Carl Zeiss Research Award was launched as an international award for research into optics in 1987 and went by this name until 2013. It is awarded every second year in rotation with the Otto Schott Research Award for special achievements in glass research. The Carl Zeiss Research Award recently received 25,000 euros und was given by the Ernst Abbe Fund which is part of the Stifterverband für die Deutsche Wissenschaft.
Since 2016, the Carl Zeiss Award for Young Researchers has recognized promising young scientists who have made outstanding contributions to optics and photonics. This award is granted as part of the Zeiss Research Award and is also financed by the Ernst Abbe Fund.
Significance
The ZEISS Research Award is intended to make a contribution to enhancing awareness of optics and photonics in science and technology. By supporting promising research projects, the award also promotes the development of innovative technologies. As the award is being presented in collaboration with a range of academic institutions, winners will also have the opportunity to expand their knowledge and network with other researchers.
Jury
The current jury consists of highly qualified and renowned personalities from the world of research including Alain Aspect, Cornelia Denz and Stefan Hell.
Winners
Winners of the Carl Zeiss Research Award
* 1990: Philippe Grangier from Orsay, James R. Taylor from London, Norbert Streibl from Erlangen
* 1992: Ahmed Zewail, Pasadena, Yoshihisa Yamamoto, Tokyo
* 1994: Heinrich Bräuninger from Garching, Bernd Aschenbach from Garching
* 1996: Eric A. Cornell from Boulder and Dieter Pohl from Zurich
* 1998: Ursula Keller from Zurich, Ferenc Krausz from Vienna
* 2000: Ursula Schmidt-Erfurth from Lübeck and Shuji Nakamura from Santa Barbara
* 2002: Stefan Hell, Göttingen
* 2004: Mark A. Kasevich, Stanford University, California
* 2006: Kurt Busch, Institute of Theoretical Solid State Physics at the University of Karlsruhe, Martin Wegener of the Institute of Applied Physics at the University of Karlsruhe
* 2007: Jun Ye of the National Institute of Standards and Technology University of Colorado Boulder
* 2009: Rainer Blatt, University of Innsbruck, Juan Ignacio Cirac Sasturain, Max Planck Institute for Quantum Optics in Garching
* 2011: James G. Fujimoto from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge
* 2013: Anne L’Huillier Lund
Winners of the Zeiss Research Award
* 2016: Fedor Jelezko and Jörg Wrachtrup
* 2018: Tobias Kippenberg and Jean-Pierre Wolf
* 2020: Jian-Wei Pan
* 2023: Immanuel Bloch
Winners of the Carl Zeiss Award for Young Researchers
* 2016: Robert Brückner, Georg Heinze and Robert Keil
* 2018: Irene Costantini, Kilian Heeg and Fabian Stutzki
* 2020: Christian Haffner, Stefan Heist and Fabian Wolf
* 2023: Simon Baier, Arindam Ghosh and Dasha Nelidova
